title: 'Queer Eye' star Karamo Brown: Why Sean Spicer got emotional saying goodbye on 'DWTS'
text:
CLOSE "Queer Eye" star Karamo Brown said his sons got death threats after he called Sean Spicer a "good guy." USA TODAY

It was hard to miss a remarkable scene on the "Dancing With the Stars" floor when "Queer Eye" star Karamo Brown was eliminated from the dance competition Monday night.

Sean Spicer, the one-time press secretary for President Trump, gave an emotional goodbye to his dance floor competitor who has has called "a friend."

Brown was one of the first, and most unlikely, voices to stand up for Spicer's controversial inclusion on the politics-free reality dance show and the duo's friendship has been inspirational. Brown admitted Monday that this came at a price.

"Day one I got backlash," Brown said backstage discussing his support for Spicer. "I started this show with people telling me, 'You’re horrible, you’re crazy, you’re stupid.' Because I showed someone — who has a different political view than mine— kindness."

With support from Trump: Sean Spicer, 17 pounds leaner, survives on 'Dancing With the Stars'

What happened on the show: 'Dancing With the Stars' recap gives all the drama

Karamo Brown and his partner Jenna Johnson are carried off the floor after being eliminated on "Dancing With the Stars." (Photo: Eric McCandless, ABC)

Brown said he had an overall educational mission coming on the popular reality competition.

"My goal coming into this was to introduce myself to people who have never seen 'Queer Eye,' to let them know who I am,” he said. "And also, my goal has always been to show how, if you can show kindness and lead with love, things can change."

He believes he saw this with Spicer, who was his trailer neighbor on the Los Angeles television lot. He saw a lot of Spicer and spoke to him about their viewpoints.

“I have literally every day been planting seeds in his heart," Brown said. "It was like, 'You know when you made this comment, this hurt me as a man. When you made this comment, it hurt me as a person of color. When you made this comment, it hurt me as a gay man.' And literally, I could see each week those seeds being planted (and) blossoming."

Sean Spicer finds out he made it through another week of the dance competition. SEAN SPICER (Photo: Eric McCandless, ABC)

Brown believes that's why Spicer reacted like he did Monday. It was mission accomplished. He touched Spicer's heart.

"He got emotional because he’s realizing that I’m not someone you should be attacking in the media," Brown said "I’m a human being. And if I can touch his heart, I’m about to go through and make a tour of Washington! I still want Trump out of office. But that was the goal."

The everyman-dancer Spicer made it through Monday's elimination easily despite earning the lowest judges' scores — with supreme fan support predominantly from supporters of President Trump. Brown does not think Spicer will make it all the way to hoisting the Mirror Ball Trophy. "But I’m proud of him. I really am proud of him, because he’s had fun every week and I think he’s exceptional," said Brown.

He believes the unlikely friendship, and the conversations, will last.

"Sean is literally someone who I would’ve never thought I could be friends with, and I’m going to walk away from here calling him a friend," he said. "I’m going to continue the conversation that we’ve had."

description: Karamo Brown believes he touched Sean Spicer's heart during their time on "Dancing With the Stars." That's why Spicer was so sad to see him voted off.
